text: hey everyone here's my first attempt at
making glue chipped glass this is sort
of a decorative glass that you might see
an antique buildings sort of a
decorative or privacy style glass and
what's interesting is it's made by
applying glue to flat glass and causing
the glue to pull chips of glass off the
surface leaving this decorative finish
so let me show you how I did it
I've never done this technique before so
I wanted to try a few different things
at once so that I could get an idea of
what will work for me for a real or for
an actual piece so I chose one piece one
piece of glass that I wouldn't mask at
all one piece that I would mask with
something very simple and one piece that
I would mask with something that had
curves and finer details to it from
reading online it seems that most people
use asphalt varnish to cover the glass
and then put like a vinyl stencil on top
for for fine masking but I didn't have
any asphalt varnish or a vinyl cutter
here so I'm just using masking tape
before applying the glue to the glass
the surface needs to be roughened
otherwise the glass will just pull off
and not actually pull any chips of glass
off so traditionally the best way that
this is accomplished is with a sand
blaster which I happen to have except my
sand blaster is currently loaded with
glass beads and shooting glass feeds at
glass is not very effective because it's
equal hardness ideally I would need
silicon carbide or alumina to shoot at
the glass and I don't have any of that
so I managed to get by a little bit on
the B I used just glass grid in my sand
blaster and it worked kind of okay but
really it could have been a lot better
for the unmasked piece I used a silicon
carbide scribe and if you don't have
access to a sand blaster it's still
possible to do glue chipping and you can
rough on the surface of the glass with
the scribe and later we'll see that I
didn't make the lines close enough
together but it still kind of worked
well enough to test at least I also used
hydrofluoric acid on the square mask
test piece and the hydrochloric acids a
very fine grain that's much finer than
the sand
blasting the glue is shipped in sort of
a dried granular form and I measured out
about 40 grams and 40 grams of glue and
then 80 grams of cold water and put
these into a beaker and let it sit for
about half an hour to an hour - to let
the water absorb I then slowly heated
the beaker on a hot plate up to a
hundred forty five degrees F and as the
mixture is being heated the viscosity
goes way down so it starts off as a
fairly gelatinous sort of blob and then
as the heat comes up it turns into a
fairly runny liquid it's probably you
know kind of like honey that even a
little bit lighter than honey at a
fairly warm room temperature the point
is that it's so runny you'll need to
build a little dam of tape or some other
material around your glass or else the
stuff will run off the edge and you
actually need a thick enough coat you
need about a sixteenth of an inch or
more of this glue on the glass in order
to make the chipping work correctly so
you'll definitely need something to
actually hold the glue in place like a
little down around the stencil as the
glue cools down it becomes thick very
quickly so even after ten or twenty
minutes the glue is gelatinous enough
again where it doesn't really need the
dam for support so I peeled all that
away and left the the coated gloop the
coated glass to sit around and dry and
that's basically it
some people will say oh you need a fan
or you need a dehumidifier box and I
think if you live in a very humid
climate that might be true but here in
California the humidity is probably 30%
or lower and so I just left them sitting
around in my shop another thing to
remember is that the glue chips will
come flying off the front of the glass
so what I did is I put them facedown in
a in a shallow pan just to catch the
glue chips and glass chips that come off
of there also if you have dogs or cats
around be aware that they're very
attracted to the scent of the glue
chipping glue because it's animal hide
glue so you want to keep them away from
the area where you're having the glass
chip off because they
try to eat the glue chips that have
glass embedded in them my pieces were
done in about a day and the glue came
off pretty easily I just used a brush to
push most of it off and then the rest of
it comes off very easy in just warm
water under the tab the unmasked piece
worked kind of okay I should have put
more scribe lines on there so that the
glue chip pattern would have been sort
of denser right now you can still see a
lot of the scribe lines and that's you
know kind of cool but not really what I
was going for the partially functional
sandblasted one was sort of okay as well
there were some areas where the glue
still didn't adhere so it seems like
glue adhesion is sort of the biggest
problem facing me here the acid etch
glass didn't chip at all I'm not really
sure if this is because the glue had too
many bubbles in it or the layer wasn't
thick enough or if just acid etching
provides not enough adhesion or too much
or something but it didn't work so I
probably wouldn't ever do that again I
think for my next piece I'll actually
get alumina and load that into my sand
blaster and do a proper stencil and
shoot that I'll put some links into the
description that show how good this
stuff can look when done properly
another neat technique is to solder the
glass once it's been glued chipped and
you can make some really cool classy
looking sort of mirrored pieces with
that okay hope that was interesting see
you next time bye
